data.title: Who is the third most famous video game composer?
data.meta_description: Junichi Masuda single handedly composed the PokÃ©mon RBY soundtrack. I don't think he gets enough credit for this. Not only is the soundtrack itself...
data.text:
I think for many Gen Xers and some millennials who actively played video games, Yuzo Koshiro might be perhaps the first video game composer they've ever heard of.

Many people back in the day didn't beat games because of their obscene difficulty and the fledgling nature of the medium rendering the audience's collective skill floor pretty low, effectively making it rare back in the day for people to see the ending of games and the credits. Making matters worse, the amount of people who worked on games that would see credit in them was also never a guarantee; lots of games didn't feature easily accessible credits and in some cases they'd erase the efforts of those working on games by enforcing aliases (Capcom was notorious for that). Meanwhile, three games in Sega's seminal Streets of Rage series, and others like Revenge of Shinobi -- all of which are commonly cited as some of the Genesis' biggest killer apps -- feature Yuzo Koshiro's name front and center on the literal title screen. People still revere the soundtrack work from those games and they always remind you who was responsible for them when you play.

And the only reason it happened was because Koshiro's mom told him to ask Sega to do that, and Sega basically went "sure why not" when asked.

Yeah, while I was aware of some Western computer game composers, I think Yuzo Koshiro was the first Japanese one where I knew his name because it was on a title screen, for Revenge of Shinobi. The 8-bit console era was full of pseudonyms like Bo (Tokuhiko Uwabo) and Konchan (Koji Kondo). I guess there was also Hip Tanaka but that heads more into nickname territory.

What kinda trips me up seeing these responses about Shimomura is like, as phenomenal as her music is and as much as she's done, I never heard anyone talk about her until recently. Whereas with Mitsuda I've been hearing musicians, media, and game fans talk about him by name since I was in high school. I didn't hear Shimomura's name until a friend of mine mentioned her work in FFXV. I didn't hear about Kirkhope until Famiboards. Some other names mentioned here I've never heard at all (even though I've heard their music).

I'm not saying that I'm an expert in this stuff by any means and I'm definitely not trying to come across like "if I haven't heard of them then they aren't famous" but if we're talking fame as in whose name is known (like who knows the name Martin O'Donnell and not just how many know "the Halo theme" for example), then Kondo, Uematsu, and Mitsuda are the only three names I've consistently heard others mention since the 90s.

Lots of good picks here. It's interesting to see a debate emerge over what makes something iconic. Work on a single massively popular work? Incredibly strong appeal in a specific part of the world versus a more general appeal worldwide? My heart says Yoko Shimomura for the range, but there are many compelling arguments.

I think you can make an argument that Kondo, Uematsu, and Mitsuda all had their most iconic work done by the 90s. Mario and Zelda started in the 80s. So did Final Fantasy, which had its incredible SNES and PS1 run in the 90s. The two Chrono games, those were 90s games too. In particular, while Kondo and Uematsu are still in the composing game, the 2000's marked the time of them stepping away from handling full OSTs in favor of the new guard. Meanwhile, while Shimomura was doing some incredible work in the 90s (SFII, Mario RPG, various Square RPGs), her most iconic works (Kingdom Hearts) are products of the 2000's and beyond. So you have a different generation of players who embraced her music. I'm one of them - I spent ages listening to KH and Mario & Luigi music long before I heard a single Chrono Trigger track (thanks, DS version!).

I knew Shimomura by name as early as high school, and while she wasn't "Koji Kondo" or "Nobuo Uematsu" levels of well-known, she was well-known enough to have a fan base. I imagine her cultural cache has only increased since then. She's still in the game with new works, and remakes with her music see her involvement (from the KH HD Remixes to Live A Live to the many Mario RPGs that she worked on).

EDIT: I also think her working on other, earlier games became more well-known in the 2010s. It took until Ryu came to Smash for talk of her doing the SFII OST was more widespread, least it was for me.

I'd argue that Koji Kondo and Nobuo Uematsu aren't the most famous composers. Their work is probably some of the most famous in the industry, and maybe that's what you mean and I misinterpreted the question, but the people themselves aren't really all that "famous".

The top three most famous composers in the industry right now are probably ConcernedApe, Toby Fox, and C418. Two extremely successful solo productions and the best selling game of all time. That's not to say these are better than Koji or Nobuo, just that these three have way more eyes on them.

To be clear, I am talking specifically name recognition over how famous or good their music is. That's a totally different conversation.

I can kind of see the other two, but this is actually the first I've seen anyone even mention ConcernedApe doing music, so that he's a composer at all is news to me!
